review.title: The Algorithm of Islamic Jurisprudence (Fiqh) with Validation of an Entscheidungsproblem
review.abstract: The historic background of algorithmic processing with regard to etymology and methodology is translated into terms of mathematical logic and Computer Science. A formal logic structure is introduced by exemplaryquestions posed to Fiqh-chapters to define alogic query language. As a foundation, ageneric algorithm for deciding Fiqh-rulings is designed to enable and further leverage rule of law (vs. rule by law) with full transparency and complete algorithmic coverage of Islamic law eventually providing legal security, legal equality, and full legal accountability.This is implemented by disentangling and reinstating classic Fiqh-methodology (usul al-Fiqh) with the expressive power of subsets of First Order Logic (FOL)sustainably substituting ad hoc reasoning with falsifiable rational argumentation. The results are discussed in formal terms of completeness, decidability and complexity of formal Fiqh-systems. AnEntscheidungsproblem for formal Fiqh-Systems is formulated and validated.

It tries to answer questions such as: Does the text mean the least group? Does the general term have a meaning that is universal or specific? Does the general term apply to all individuals? Obviously, all these questions of language are common, whether natural or formalized like algebraic logic (QLn & Qgic). Fiqh also provides studies on the case of the individual contained in a general term. It has been recognized that the individual can be addressed without using a general linguistic formula. In such a case, the reference is made by using a description that applies to the individual without further details. sections.heading: B. LOGIC & COMPUTER SCIENCE
sections.text: Since the beginnings of algorithmic processing, namely computer science in the early 1940s, it has been recognized that any technology for automating logical conclusions could have enormous potential to solve problems by drawing automated conclusions from a given fact. To this day, the most powerful and expressive formal method for describing and analyzing information is First Order Logic (FOL). In this abstract and formal context, logic should be merely the concept of what follows from what, for example, if two statements x, y are true, then a third statement z can be derived from it, while it does not matter whether one of the statements is actually true! The formal, i.e. syntactic quality is simply that if x and y are true, then z must also be a logically valid statement.

sections.heading: 11. COMPLETENESS AND DECIDABILITY OF FIQHSYSTEMS
sections.text: Some famous formal systems that are weaker than FOL, but both complete and decidable are among others: Propositional calus, the set of FOL validities in the Sign, the set of FOL validities in a-Que, and the set of first-order Boolean algebras. It is also known that any complete, recurred and recurred initial description of the theory of first order is decidable. 36 The term decidable refers to the decision problem that raises the question of the existence of an effective method of determining membership in a set of formulas, or more precisely, an algorithm theory that can return a true or false value. Logical systems such as propositional logic are decidable if the membership in its set of logically valid formulas (or theorems) can be determined effectively.

sections.heading: 14. ALGORITHMIC IMPLEMENTATION
sections.text: The need to view Fiqh within a formal framework of logic is complementary to the urgent need to rewrite the Fiqh reference works in a style that is easy to understand by contemporary readers. Furthermore, the rewriting should take into account the need to provide solutions to practical problems in an increasingly complex and differentiated world. Among other things, this stance is supported by Al-Zuhayli (1350 AH / 1923 AD -): there is nothing that would preclude a recast of Islamic Fiqh in the form of articles that would make it easier for a judge, lawyer or ordinary person to refer to his judgments. Indeed, this is one of the most pressing needs of our time. Old books of Fiqh are not simply referenced for a decision on a particular issue, except by a specialist. Indeed, the entire body of Fiqh needs to be reorganized and rearranged.
